Yes,it may help mild to moderate depression. I doubt it would help major depressive disorder. I think also there is a risk that stoicism could increase depression. I am more of a taoist or epicurean myself which is not too very different from stoicism. That which you seek is causing you to seek. Most people think happiness is getting what you want,but really happiness is about wanting what you’ve got. things are only bad in comparison with something better.and the better is only a picture in your mind. better to have the terrible problems you have than to have both your legs cut off. your life is pretty much about as good as you make your mind up for it to be.

No. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, which is quite effective, was partially inspired by and shares some elements with Stoic ethics. However, philosophies are not therapies and Stoicism can no more cure depression than it can cure a broken leg.
I think a more useful question is whether depression can cure stoicism.
